summary: This document is an email chain from October 2020 regarding a request for files from the Florida State Attorney's Office related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The requester is seeking missing items, specifically grand jury transcripts and signed search warrant affidavits for Epstein's residence, to assist in a related prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell. The correspondence highlights the public records process and the difficulty in obtaining certain sealed or unfiled materials.

persons.name: Brianna Coakley
persons.context: She is the Division Chief for the Human Trafficking and ICAC unit in the Office of the State Attorney for the 15th Judicial Circuit (Florida) and is the point of contact for releasing case files related to the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the prior investigation and prosecution for which files are being requested.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The request for files is to assist in the requester's office's related prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: The document references a prosecution of Maxwell that is related to the prior Epstein investigation, implying their alleged criminal association.
Coakley's office (State Attorney) conducted a prior investigation and prosecution of Epstein, making her the custodian of related files.

events.title: Request for Missing Epstein Files
events.description: An email is sent to Brianna Coakley noting that grand jury transcripts and signed search warrant affidavits for Epstein's residence are missing from the provided files and requesting steps to obtain them.

events.title: Discussion of Discovery Files
events.description: Email exchange where Brianna Coakley clarifies if the requester is seeking discovery materials (police reports, pictures, etc.) from the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The Florida State Attorney's Office (15th Judicial Circuit) possessed investigation files on Jeffrey Epstein but was not in possession of a transcript of the grand jury proceeding.
Official, signed copies of the affidavit and warrant to search Jeffrey Epstein's residence were not included in the released files and may not have been filed with the clerk of courts.
The request for these files was made to assist in a separate, related prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell.
The correspondence operates under Florida's broad public records law, which makes most official communications subject to public disclosure.
